displayed_text: Patient: I can tell him thanks for buying her a new car. Doctor: He didn’t buy it. Healthcare Professional: She probably bought it (chuckles) Patient: Oh it’s you – it’s your it’s everybodies - it’s both your monies; it’s not just - Doctor: No, no, he is just, yeah. No, but he’s really trying to drive it as much as he can right now. Healthcare Professional: Yours? Doctor: The problem, well the worst thing is my son sent a picture to all of his friends and you know my sister; he sent it to his cousin, my sister’s kids and so they told my sister and I hadn’t had a chance to tell her that I bought this car. And she’s like, “Are you out of your mind? You bought N____ a Mercedes?” (Chuckles) Healthcare Professional: Oh they thought it was N___’s car. Doctor: He sort of - sent the text out as if it was his car with a picture of my car. HCP OH! Family Member: His car. Oh my! Doctor: But now he doesn’t have any car because he’s in college. He doesn’t have - HCP Oh okay! Family Member: The Mercedes Patient: He’s lucky he’s having college paid for.

Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Because they’re not all the same. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so you always fuss about that. Because there’s other people giving high-dose vitamin C Patient: Yeah. Doctor: but you can’t guarantee the product. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Here I’m happy to say the product is definitely of high grade. Uh, but you’ve got to give it two days out of every week. Okay? So logistically that means as long as they are given twenty-four hours apart, you can just come up once, and the study pays for you to stay overnight at a hotel. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? But that’s weekly. Patient: Okay, well I - Doctor: So like you’ll come up. You’ll get the one day where you get the chemo and the vitamin C. The next day 24 hours later you get vitamin C and you can go home.

Family Member: Yeah. You, you supply pill or do we have to use our insurance? Doctor: We supply the pills. Family Member: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Um, hum. Doctor: Yeah same with uh the study is to see if a second pill helps this pill work better so if you’re in the group that gets the second pill, we provide that too. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So there’s nothing for you to do. Family Member: As long, as long as he get – as long as he’s on it? Doctor: Correct. Family Member: And they said he does this three months and then he comes back and get the pills? Healthcare Professional: Um, hum. Family Member: Right.

Patient: Yeah. You have. Doctor: Because we did it before the testosterone, during the testosterone, during the enzalutamide, and we try to look at how those treatments affect it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I’ll, I’ll find out. Patient: Alright. Doctor: So- Family Member: I wanted, I want your input, uh but we couldn’t just give him that - because he is all at that level of three injections of testosterone, he’s a perfect candidate just for that immune thing just to see? (Beeping) Doctor: Well, the immune thing is normally I, I don’t. We’re not allowed to give anything unless it’s in a disease where it’s been approved- Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: because the cost is so very high, the hospital won’t let us do anything. So normally what we have to do is go through the insurance company, tell them what we wanted to do, they deny it, you write letters. So it’s not something that I can just do it tomorrow. Family Member: So you can’t ask-? Doctor: Now you, you know, who have, you’re a person of means, that maybe you could just pay for it, but I haven’t really, I don’t know what the avenue is to do that. (Laughs) Family Member: Well-

Healthcare Professional: Okay. Doctor: Beautiful. Okay. Need any refills on anything? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. So hang on and watch out for the uh yeah uh the diet and we’ll see you back in six weeks. Piece of cake. Patient: Six weeks? Doctor: Sure. Is that legit? Are you going to behave for six weeks? Patient: Oh, I always behave. Patient: Life is so boring. Doctor: Did I give you the nutrition book last time? Patient: No. Doctor: Oh, good. Parting gift. Patient: Parting gift?

Patient: So we get the shot right here? Doctor: Yeah. Yes. So how do you like the new trailer? Slowly, then the scans, everything is going to move here. Patient: Really? Doctor: Two years. Patient: Two years? Yeah. Family Member: Are they building a bigger building? Doctor: They are. Okay. That’s fine. Going to expand quite a bit. We were kind of bursting at the seams there so they needed to do it, but it’s going to be on a much bigger scale. Patient: I like coming here better. Doctor: Yes. Definitely. I mean it’s much more in and out, it’s a smaller place, and there are- Patient: It’s hectic down there. Doctor: Yes. Yes. Patient: Tell you? (Laughter) Doctor: Yeah. It is a much bigger place. But it needs to be with the hospital and everything.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you know, all the new studies are like hey, radium and phone a friend, you know, radium and Xtandi, radium and chemo, radium and whatever. So, they’re all in studies but not standard of care yet. I’m gonna pause right there and see how you guys are doing. This is not a test. There’s no test. No test. Family Member: Okay, he was asking when we were waiting for you. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: If the treatment you’re going to give him is going to make him feel better Patient: Yes. Family Member: or is he still gonna feel fatigued and miserable. Doctor: You should feel better. I know it’s counterintuitive. Like wait, you’re poisoning me and you’re telling me I would feel better. I think you feel bad because your cancer is not controlled, Patient: Okay. Doctor: you know, and some people could have a PSA at three thousand and feel better than you. Some people could have a PSA of thirty and feel worse than you. I don’t really care what the number is. I do know that your cancer isn’t treated. So, when you have untreated cancer you just don’t feel good. Patient: Okay, because I like to work outside and do stuff Doctor: Um hum Patient: and I do that but then it seems like the next day, does that have a part to it or no?

Doctor: I had some Spanish-Portuguese, maybe Doctor: One of my grand, great-grandmothers had a little thing on the side. I don’t know. Doctor: Yeah, the joke is uh – Patient: He used to say that all the time, yeah. Doctor: Mommy’s baby, daddy’s maybe. Is that what I’ve heard? (Laughs) Family Member: It’s twenty-three and me --- Doctor: One of them tells you like how much Neanderthal you have. Ancestry didn’t tell you that. Family Member: It didn’t tell you --- Doctor: No, I wanted to know how much Neanderthal was in me. (Laughs) Doctor: Right, right. Patient: But that’s, uh, not so much the case anymore. That --- Doctor: Or how much – I’ve been watching these alien shows. I wanna learn how much alien Patient: Oh good, good.

Patient: Sure. Sure. Doctor: You could go on before you uh, I think their trial is a, so it’s called a phase one trial. So what does that mean? So phase one traditionally was uh a dose-finding trial. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So it determines how toxic things were. Patient: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: So with drugs what will often happen is a patient on a phase one where you came at an early stage you’d get a very low dose, probably too low to have toxicity but too low to be effective. And when you get to the high dose, it might be plenty to be effective but toxic, so you’d always sort of be Goldilocks at the end. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: For this, I’ve got a, I think for this, the trial, they were able to use the experience with Germany to say you probably could start about here. You don’t have to start way down here. And I don’t think it’s the same exactly like a regular drug phase one. So I think they’re kind of already in a in a sort of Goldilocks spot. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: So that’s the only difference between you know in Germany everybody gets, they individualize it based on what they looked at is how much of the scan is your cancer taking off. They try, they, they describe what they said that if you took up that much material, you need to get this much. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So they give, they dose it based on how much of an exposure. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yep so that’s already on deck. And you know the thing is as time moves on you will get that test repeated so that’s good for that moment in time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But after chemo that profile will change again. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we will most likely do both. We’ll check your tissue and we now also check your circulating blood. Patient: Sure. Doctor: For things. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So it’s uh technology moves on. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And so does your cancer. So that profile will look different after we give chemotherapy. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So new things might pop up. Patient: Okay. And I had some other questions Doctor: Yeah. Patient: about other clinical trial options. Doctor: Oh, yeah, there’s zillions. We are not gonna run out. (& PAT high five each other) Patient: Well yeah, it is. Doctor: I’m not gonna run out, Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m not gonna run out. The time will just be when your body poops out and it’s not safe for us to continue. It’s just - Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: - stupid to continue. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Potassium. Doctor: That's right. That's for the secondary causes of hypertension. Okay. Okay, so that is, so that's that approach. The third approach is clinical trials. And clinical trials in general are where we're testing some intervention to see if it is helpful or not. The two that we have for people who have biochemical recurrence, there's one that's a natural products. And there's one that is a medicine called a PARP inhibitor. Patient: Mm. Doctor: The mainstay of treatment of prostate cancer today is hormone therapy, neither of those two therapies are hormone therapy. Okay, so the clinical trials that we have would be doing, they would be giving you some intervention, but it would not be a hormone therapy intervention. So sometimes people like that because they don't want to get started on hormone therapy. Because if your disease progresses, you got to get started on hormone therapy- Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: -and sometimes people, you know, don't want to be in a clinical trial. And so these are, the three general options. Family Member: Out of the three which one would you recommend. Doctor: Well, let me tell you a little bit more about what what the clinical trials entail, because then I'll tell you what I think, based on our conversation last time to what we should look into first. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: So the two clinical trials one is called the MAP study. And I might have briefly mentioned this last time, this is a study of muscadine grapeseed extract. Family Member: Yes you did. Doctor: Yeah. So this is a study- is a randomized study for people with a particular genotype. So what that means is what what we know is that when some people take antioxidants like you know, these a lot like pomegranate or the muscadine grapeseed extract- Family Member: Mhm.

Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Still if you cough or pick up a heavy weight – Patient: Mm,hmm. Doctor: - still even a few years from now maybe a drop or two might come out. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Hmm, okay. (Pause) Doctor: It means that um there’s not enough prostate cancer cells to be detectable by the blood test. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: There could either be zero or there could be some somewhere. It’s just not enough for it to be detectible. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So therefore getting a CAT scan, bone scan, it doesn’t, it’s kind of a waste of time because even if something’s there it’s not enough to actually be seen. Family Member: Be seen, okay. Doctor: On a scan.

Patient: The, no, the, I think Doctor: The last medication? Patient: No, I think the fifth. I think the fifth. Doctor: The fifth of September. Patient: Yeah, the fifth. Doctor: Okay. So, I’m going to then, uh, give you one with this date, with the end of September date. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because that’s when you’ll be due. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: And look, look I need three still. I need that one, and I needed the one for, from that scooter, and I need Doctor: But, I told you I’m not giving you for the scooter. Patient: I mean, not scooter, I mean the walker.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Retired: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Retired

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Family Member: Right. Right. Doctor: But we haven’t had a scan since April of last year. So we might as well get one this year. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: See how things are. You know? See how the lymph nodes and bone stuff is doing just to make sure we don’t have to do anything exciting. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You okay with that? So that’s the CAT scan again, there’s the chest, the bone in the pelvis, and then the bone scan, which is basically stuff like that. Just to make sure. Patient: Hum. Hum. Doctor: And we’ll compare it to all the ones before. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: This is not a huge jump. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Nothing that I’m going to freak out about. But we want to be prepared in case it’s starting to wake up. Patient: Hum.
